Matrix Factorization is a simple way to do collaborative filtering.

MN1×N2=UN1×dVd×N2M_{N_1\times N2}=U_{N_1\times d}V_{d\times N_2}MN1​×N2​=UN1​×d​Vd×N2​​

The main idea is that d≪min(N1,N2)d \ll min(N_1, N_2)d≪min(N1​,N2​) and is smaller than the rank of MMM. Actually, it is equivalent to learn a low rank matrix (with rank ddd) that is similar to MMM.

The reason why we can learn such a low rank matrix is that:

  • We assume many columns in MMM should look similar
  • MMM is sparse and we can use the low rank matrix to fill the missing data.

Probabilistic Matrix Factorization

Let Ω\OmegaΩ contain the pairs (i,j)(i, j)(i,j) that MijM_{ij}Mij​ is non-zero. And Ωui\Omega_{u_i}Ωui​​ the rated objects for user iii, Ωvj\Omega_{v_j}Ωvj​​ the users who rated for object jjj.

Assume

ui∼N(0,λ−1I),i=1,...,N1vj∼N(0,λ−1I),j=1,...,N2\begin{aligned} u_i\sim N(0, \lambda^{-1} I), i=1,...,N_1\\ v_j\sim N(0, \lambda^{-1} I), j=1,...,N_2 \end{aligned}ui​∼N(0,λ−1I),i=1,...,N1​vj​∼N(0,λ−1I),j=1,...,N2​​

And

Mij∼N(uiTvj,σ2)M_{ij}\sim N(u_i^T v_j, \sigma^2)Mij​∼N(uiT​vj​,σ2)

Though for MMM as rating, it does not make sense to use a normal distribution. However, this assumption works well.

And we need to maximize:

p(Mo,U,V)=[∏(i,j)∈Ωp(Mij∣ui,vj)]×[∏i=1N1p(ui)][∏j=1N2p(vj)]p(M_o, U, V)=[\prod_{(i,j)\in \Omega}p(M_{ij}|u_i, v_j)]\times [\prod_{i=1}^{N_1}p(u_i)][\prod_{j=1}^{N_2}p(v_j)]p(Mo​,U,V)=[(i,j)∈Ω∏​p(Mij​∣ui​,vj​)]×[i=1∏N1​​p(ui​)][j=1∏N2​​p(vj​)]

Where MoM_oMo​ are the observed terms of MMM.

Notice that for general assumption, this is a problem with missing values and should use EM to solve iteratively. However, applying the gaussian assumption to this posteriori, we have:

And we apply derivation on them directly,

∇uiL=∑j∈Ωui1σ2(Mij−uiTvj)vj−λui=0∇vjL=∑i∈Ωvj1σ2(Mij−uiTvj)ui−λvj=0\begin{aligned} \nabla_{u_i}\mathcal{L}=\sum_{j\in\Omega_{u_i}}\frac{1}{\sigma^2}(M_{ij}-u_i^Tv_j)v_j-\lambda u_i=0\\ \nabla_{v_j}\mathcal{L}=\sum_{i\in\Omega_{v_j}}\frac{1}{\sigma^2}(M_{ij}-u_i^Tv_j)u_i-\lambda v_j=0 \end{aligned}∇ui​​L=j∈Ωui​​∑​σ21​(Mij​−uiT​vj​)vj​−λui​=0∇vj​​L=i∈Ωvj​​∑​σ21​(Mij​−uiT​vj​)ui​−λvj​=0​

Therefore

ui=(λσ2I+∑j∈ΩuivjvjT)−1(∑j∈ΩuiMijvj)vj=(λσ2I+∑i∈ΩvjuiuiT)−1(∑i∈ΩvjMijui)\begin{aligned} u_i=(\lambda\sigma^2I+\sum_{j\in\Omega_{u_i}}v_jv_j^T)^{-1}(\sum_{j\in\Omega_{u_i}}M_{ij}v_j)\\ v_j=(\lambda\sigma^2I+\sum_{i\in\Omega_{v_j}}u_iu_i^T)^{-1}(\sum_{i\in\Omega_{v_j}}M_{ij}u_i)\\ \end{aligned}ui​=(λσ2I+j∈Ωui​​∑​vj​vjT​)−1(j∈Ωui​​∑​Mij​vj​)vj​=(λσ2I+i∈Ωvj​​∑​ui​uiT​)−1(i∈Ωvj​​∑​Mij​ui​)​

And for this, we need a coordinate ascent algorithm to iteratively get the optimum.

Relation with ridge regression

From the objective function, if we see from the vjv_jvj​'s point of view, it is basically a ridge regression.

So the model is a set of N1+N2N_1+N_2N1​+N2​ coupled ridge regression problems.

If we remove the prior term, which makes

vj=(∑i∈ΩvjuiuiT)−1(∑i∈ΩvjMijui)v_j=(\sum_{i\in\Omega_{v_j}}u_iu_i^T)^{-1}(\sum_{i\in\Omega_{v_j}}M_{ij}u_i)vj​=(i∈Ωvj​​∑​ui​uiT​)−1(i∈Ωvj​​∑​Mij​ui​)

It is the least square solution (not MAP any more). But in this case, the assure that the inversibility, each object must be rated by at least ddd users, which is probably not the case.

Nonnegative Matrix Factorization

Some times, we need UUU and VVV nonnegative. For example, let MijM_{ij}Mij​ be the number of times word iii appears in document jjj. We have two object function:

Choice 1: Squared error objective

∣∣X−WH∣∣2=∑i∑j(Xij−(WH)ij)2\begin{aligned} ||X-WH||^2&=\sum_i\sum_j(X_{ij}-(WH)_{ij})^2 \end{aligned}∣∣X−WH∣∣2​=i∑​j∑​(Xij​−(WH)ij​)2​

Choice 2: Divergence objective

D(X∣∣WH)=−∑i∑j[Xijln(WH)ij−(WH)ij]D(X||WH)=-\sum_i\sum_j[X_{ij}ln(WH)_{ij}-(WH)_{ij}]D(X∣∣WH)=−i∑​j∑​[Xij​ln(WH)ij​−(WH)ij​]

Notice apart from the objective function, there should be nonnegative values.

And for these problems, we will use multiplicative algorithms to minimize the objective function. The detail algorithms are in Algorithms for non-negative matrix factorization.

And for squared error we have:

Hkj←Hkj(WTX)kj(WTWH)kjWik←Wik(XHT)ik(WHHT)ik\begin{aligned} H_{kj}\leftarrow H_{kj}\frac{(W^TX)_{kj}}{(W^TWH)_{kj}}\\ W_{ik}\leftarrow W_{ik}\frac{(XH^T)_{ik}}{(WHH^T)_{ik}} \end{aligned}Hkj​←Hkj​(WTWH)kj​(WTX)kj​​Wik​←Wik​(WHHT)ik​(XHT)ik​​​

as an iterative algorithm.

Probabilistically, the squared error implies a Gaussian distribution

Xij∼N(ΣkWijHkj,σ2)X_{ij}\sim N(\Sigma_kW_{ij}H_{kj}, \sigma^2)Xij​∼N(Σk​Wij​Hkj​,σ2)

It is incorrect for nonnegative value, but still, it works well.

And for divergence objective

Hkj←HkjΣiWikXij/(WH)ijΣiWikWik←WikΣjHkjXij/(WH)ijΣjHkj\begin{aligned} H_{kj}\leftarrow H_{kj}\frac{\Sigma_i W_{ik}X_{ij}/(WH)_{ij}}{\Sigma_i W_{ik}}\\ W_{ik}\leftarrow W_{ik}\frac{\Sigma_j H_{kj}X_{ij}/(WH)_{ij}}{\Sigma_j H_{kj}} \end{aligned}Hkj​←Hkj​Σi​Wik​Σi​Wik​Xij​/(WH)ij​​Wik​←Wik​Σj​Hkj​Σj​Hkj​Xij​/(WH)ij​​​

as an iterative algorithm.

The probabilistic interpretation is

Xij∼Pois((WH)ij)X_{ij}\sim Pois((WH)_{ij})Xij​∼Pois((WH)ij​)

Therefore,

ln(P(Xij∣W,H))=ln⁡(WH)ijXijXij!e−(WH)ij=Xijln⁡(WH)ij−(WH)ij+constant\begin{aligned} ln(P(X_{ij}|W, H))&=\ln{\frac{(WH)_{ij}^{X_{ij}}}{X_{ij}!}e^{-(WH)_{ij}}}\\ &=X_{ij}\ln{(WH)_{ij}}-(WH)_{ij} + constant \end{aligned}ln(P(Xij​∣W,H))​=lnXij​!(WH)ijXij​​​e−(WH)ij​=Xij​ln(WH)ij​−(WH)ij​+constant​

Hence, minimizing the divergence objective function is equivalent to maximize the probability.
